content.m0_2:
0.2 Solar Masses

Deep or Fully Convective Low Mass MS star

The star is in a very stable state, fusing (or burning) hydrogen atoms in the core. The star is convective throughout, rather than just having convective zones, as is found in more massive stars of around a solar mass or more.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. While there is very little hydrogen in the core, a shell surrounding the core continues to burn; we can think of an onion analogy where the star has layers, and in this case there is an outer hydrogen layer, and an inner helium layer. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes colour to give a more red appearance.

Helium White Dwarf

Main-sequence stars of around half a solar mass or less do not become hot enough to burn helium in their cores. The star burns out all of its hydrogen and ends its evolution as a helium white dwarf, composed mainly of helium-4 nuclei.
content.m0_65:
0.65 Solar Masses

Deep or Fully Convective Low Mass MS star

The star is in a very stable state, fusing (or burning) hydrogen atoms in the core. The star is convective throughout, rather than just having convective zones, as is found in more massive stars of around a solar mass or more.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. While there is very little hydrogen in the core, a shell surrounding the core continues to burn; we can think of an onion analogy where the star has layers, and in this case there is an outer hydrogen layer, and an inner helium layer. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes colour to give a more red appearance.

Helium White Dwarf

Main-sequence stars of around half a solar mass or less do not become hot enough to burn helium in their cores. The star burns out all of its hydrogen and ends its evolution as a helium white dwarf, composed mainly of helium-4 nuclei.
content.m1:
1 Solar Mass

Main Sequence

The stage longest inhabited by a star. The star remains stable for billions of years burning (or fusing) hydrogen at its core.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium.

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. While there is very little hydrogen in the core, a shell surrounding the core continues to burn; we can think of an onion analogy where the star has layers, and in this case there is an outer hydrogen layer, and an inner helium layer. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes colour to give a more red appearance.

Core Helium Burning

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Eventually the core reaches a temperature so high the density of matter is high enough that gravity is counteracted, and the star to expands and subsequently cools.

Asymptotic Giant Branch

After a star has consumed the helium in its core, fusion then continues in a shell around a hot core of carbon and oxygen, but below the hydrogen burning shell, we can revisit our onion analogy adding an outer hydrogen layer, an inner carbon/oxygen core, and a helium layer between. The outer layers of the star swell, cool and change colour again as it did in the Red Giant Branch phase.

Thermally-Pulsing Asymptotic Giant Branch

The helium burning shell produces a hundred to a million times as much energy produced by the hydrogen burning shell over a short time period. This causes energy bursts, in the form of thermal pulses between these layers.

Carbon/Oxygen White Dwarf

If the star is massive enough, as in this case, it will be able to fuse helium into carbon and oxygen via the triple-alpha process, but will not be hot enough to fuse carbon-oxygen core into heavier elements. The hydrogen and helium layers will be cast out into a planetary nebula, leaving the carbon-oxygen core.

As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes colour to give a more red appearance.

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Carbon/Oxygen White Dwarf

If the star is massive enough, as in this case, it will be able to fuse helium into carbon and oxygen via the triple-alpha process, but will not be hot enough to fuse carbon-oxygen core into heavier elements. The hydrogen and helium layers will be cast out into a planetary nebula, leaving the carbon-oxygen core.

Carbon/Oxygen White Dwarf

6 Solar Mass

Main Sequence

The stage longest inhabited by a star. The star remains stable for millions of years burning (or fusing) hydrogen at its core.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium.

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. While there is very little hydrogen in the core, a shell surrounding the core continues to burn; we can think of an onion analogy where the star has layers, and in this case there is an outer hydrogen layer, and an inner helium layer. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes colour to give a more red appearance.

Core Helium Burning

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Eventually the core reaches a temperature so high the density of matter is high enough that gravity is counteracted, and the star to expands and subsequently cools.

Asymptotic Giant Branch

After a star has consumed the helium in its core, fusion then continues in a shell around a hot core of carbon and oxygen, but below the hydrogen burning shell, we can revisit our onion analogy adding an outer hydrogen layer, an inner carbon/oxygen core, and a helium layer between. The outer layers of the star swell, cool and change colour again as it did in the Red Giant Branch phase.

Thermally-Pulsing Asymptotic Giant Branch

The helium burning shell produces a hundred to a million times as much energy produced by the hydrogen burning shell over a short time period. This causes energy bursts, in the form of thermal pulses between these layers.

Carbon/Oxygen White Dwarf

If the star is massive enough, as in this case, it will be able to fuse helium into carbon and oxygen via the triple-alpha process, but will not be hot enough to fuse carbon-oxygen core into heavier elements. The hydrogen and helium layers will be cast out into a planetary nebula, leaving the carbon-oxygen core.
content.m10:
10 Solar Mass

Main Sequence

The stage longest inhabited by a star. The star remains stable for millions of years burning (or fusing) hydrogen at its core.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium.

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. While there is very little hydrogen in the core, a shell surrounding the core continues to burn; we can think of an onion analogy where the star has layers, and in this case there is an outer hydrogen layer, and an inner helium layer. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes colour to give a more red appearance.

Core Helium Burning

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Eventually the core reaches a temperature so high the density of matter is high enough that gravity is counteracted, and the star to expands and subsequently cools.

Asymptotic Giant Branch

After a star has consumed the helium in its core, fusion then continues in a shell around a hot core of carbon and oxygen, but below the hydrogen burning shell, we can revisit our onion analogy adding an outer hydrogen layer, an inner carbon/oxygen core, and a helium layer between. The outer layers of the star swell, cool and change colour again as it did in the Red Giant Branch phase.

Neutron Star

A star of more than 8 times the mass of the Sun will be able to reach a temperature in the core that makes it suitable to fuse carbon and oxygen atoms to make heavier elements. The elements carry on fusing, adding more and more layers like in the onion analogy. However, the fusion stops with iron, and since energy is no longer being released from nuclear reactions, gravity causes the core to collapse, and the outer layers of the star explodes in a supernova, a very bright event lasting months, leaving a Neutron Star behind, a star with a mass greater than the Sun, but around the size of Brooklyn. Neutron stars spin very rapidly given by their high mass and low radius. Since most of the stars radiation is spent during the Supernova, the Neutron Star is very dim, giving out radio waves like beacons from the top and bottom of the magnetic fields. Coupled with the spin, these beacons act like a distant radio-lighthouse in space.

20 Solar Mass

Main Sequence

The stage longest inhabited by a star. The star remains stable for millions of years burning (or fusing) hydrogen at its core.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium.

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes colour to give a more red appearance.

Core Helium Burning

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Eventually the core reaches a temperature so high the density of matter is high enough that gravity is counteracted, and the star to expands and subsequently cools.

Asymptotic Giant Branch

After a star has consumed the helium in its core, fusion then continues in a shell around a hot core of carbon and oxygen, but below the hydrogen burning shell, we can revisit our onion analogy adding an outer hydrogen layer, an inner carbon/oxygen core, and a helium layer between. The outer layers of the star swell, cool and change colour again as it did in the Red Giant Branch phase.

Neutron Star

A star of more than 8 times the mass of the Sun will be able to reach a temperature in the core that makes it suitable to fuse carbon and oxygen atoms to make heavier elements. The elements carry on fusing, adding more and more layers like in the onion analogy. However, the fusion stops with iron, and since energy is no longer being released from nuclear reactions, gravity causes the core to collapse, and the outer layers of the star explodes in a supernova, a very bright event lasting months, leaving a Neutron Star behind, a star with a mass greater than the Sun, but around the size of Brooklyn. Neutron stars spin very rapidly given by their high mass and low radius. Since most of the stars radiation is spent during the Supernova, the Neutron Star is very dim, giving out radio waves like beacons from the top and bottom of the magnetic fields. Coupled with the spin, these beacons act like a distant radio-lighthouse in space.
content.m30:
30 Solar Masses

Main Sequence

The stage longest inhabited by a star. The star remains stable for millions of years burning (or fusing) hydrogen at its core.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium.

Core Helium Burning

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Eventually the core reaches a temperature so high the density of matter is high enough that gravity is counteracted, and the star to expands and subsequently cools.

Main Sequence Naked Helium Star

During this stage, the star is giving off rapid stellar winds, these winds strip the star of its hydrogen envelope, leaving the helium core behind. At this stage the star appears blue, and has a very, very hot surface temperature.

Wolf-Rayet Star

By now, the star is no longer fusing elements in its core, and its outer layers are fading away due to the rapid stellar winds of up to 2000km per second, which is significantly shortening its lifetime, as a supernova looms.

Black Hole

Due to the lack of activity in the core, there is no pressure to stop gravity from causing the core to collapse. A supernova occurs, and the core collapses. Left over is a Black hole, an object with such a strong gravitational field, that anything that falls on it can’t escape, not even light (hence the name 'Black').

Due to the lack of activity in the core, there is no pressure to stop gravity from causing the core to collapse. A supernova occurs, and the core collapses. Left over is a Black hole, an object with such a strong gravitational field, that anything that falls on it can’t escape, not even light (hence the name 'Black').
